item.title: Loved and Hated, Former Premier of Thailand Is Erased From Textbook
item.description: In a plugged-in Thailand, it is unclear to what degree the military junta can remove Thaksin Shinawatra from the public’s consciousness.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Thaksin Shinawatra in Hong Kong in 2012. He was in power from 2001 to 2006.

item.title: Kashmiris Cope With Flooding, and Resentment of India
item.description: A week after disaster struck, many say that the aid response by the government is too little, too late.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA and NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: A Kashmiri woman on Monday inside her house in Chak village, south of Srinagar, which had more rain on Sunday after flooding devastated the area last week.

item.title: Kerry Says U.S. Is Open to Talking to Iran, Even as Ayatollah Is Dismissive
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry spoke at a Paris conference on the Iraqi security crisis, as Iran’s supreme leader said the American plan for bombing ISIS was absurd.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry arrived at a conference in Paris on how to counter the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Obama Must Get Congress’s Backing for the Fight Against ISIS
item.description: We should not stretch the open-ended 9/11 authorization to cover new airstrikes.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM KAINE

item.title: Memo From France: French Premier’s Push Toward Center Opens Rift on the Left
item.description: Prime Minister Manuel Valls has called a rare confidence vote for Tuesday, as he tries to corral his Socialist Party away from what he calls “old Socialism.”
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN and MAÏA de la BAUME
item.media:description: Prime Minister Manuel Valls of France last month in Paris. Mr. Valls has called a rare confidence vote for Tuesday.

item.title: U.N. Moves Peacekeepers in Golan Over Safety Fears
item.description: The United Nations said it moved members of its Golan peacekeeping force to the Israeli-controlled side because the area had “deteriorated severely.”
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Obama to Announce Expanded Effort Against Ebola
item.description: President Obama is to announce on Tuesday an expansion of military and medical resources to combat the virus’s spread, officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents looked on as body lay in a Monrovia, Liberia, street on Monday. The city has been hard hit by the Ebola outbreak.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: To Crush ISIS, Make a Deal With Assad
item.description: Syria has no “moderate opposition” to help us. But maybe Assad could.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By AHMAD SAMIH KHALIDI

item.title: From Turkey, ISIS Draws Steady Stream of Recruits
item.description: A neighborhood in the tourist district of the capital, Ankara, has become a hub for wooing new members of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, even as the group holds Turkish hostages.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, hand raised, and Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu, to his right, in August, leaving the Haci Bayram Veli Mosque in Ankara, the capital, where the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria is known to recruit new members.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Adam Brookes on China, Secrets and Spies
item.description: Adam Brookes, formerly a longtime China correspondent for the BBC, has written “Night Heron,” a suspenseful page-turner that takes the reader from China’s far west to the streets of Beijing, pulsing with power, danger and intrigue.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: ‘Painful’ Split Would Follow a Yes Vote, Scots Are Told
item.description: In advance of Thursday’s referendum on Scotland’s independence, Prime Minister David Cameron emphasized the economic risks of a “yes” vote.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Kiev Offers ‘Special Status’ for Breakaway Regions
item.description: The Ukrainian government proposed a law granting “special status” to the Donetsk and Luhansk regions, but it was unclear whether that would be acceptable to Russia.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Open Source: Cairo Courtroom Erupts in Celebration at Dissidents’ Release
item.description: Democracy activists cheered as an Egyptian judge ordered the release on bail of three prominent dissidents jailed for attending a protest last year.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:credit: Ravy Shaker/El Shorouk Newspaper, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Egyptian blogger Alaa Abd El Fattah's mother, sister and wife cheered in court on Monday as a judge ordered his release on bail.

item.title: Many Questions Arise From Scottish Independence Vote
item.description: The referendum itself contains only one question, but it gives rise to many others: What is at stake? What would become of the Union Jack? What would a disunited kingdom be called?
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: At War Blog: A Sister, and Brother, in Arms
item.description: When Teresa Fazio’s brother Mike followed her into the military, the Marine in her was impressed. The sister in her was terrified.
item.dc:creator: By TERESA FAZIO
item.media:description: Teresa Fazio receiving her Marine Corps commission in 2002, with her two brothers, Chris on the left and Mike on the right.

item.title: Out There: A Pioneer as Elusive as His Particle
item.description: The Nobel laureate Peter Higgs, 85, whose public appearances have been as rare and fleeting as the tracks of the Higgs boson, discussed his life’s work in an interview at an Edinburgh cafe.
item.dc:creator: By DENNIS OVERBYE

item.title: Egyptian Activist Alaa Abd El Fattah Is Released on Bail
item.description: Mr. Abd El Fattah, a blogger from a prominent family of writers and activists, was jailed under a new law restricting protests but released by a judge who cited potential “embarrassment.”
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MERNA THOMAS

item.title: Afghan Court Confirms 5 Death Sentences in Rape Case That Led to Outrage
item.description: Five of the seven defendants in a gang rape case were condemned to death, despite their claims that their confessions were extracted through torture.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Qaisullah was one of the defendants sentenced to death in a rape case in Kabul.

item.title: Maker of Costly Hepatitis C Drug Sovaldi Strikes Deal on Generics for Poor Countries
item.description: The agreements between Gilead Sciences and seven Indian firms seek to provide treatment to those infected in 91 developing nations.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Sovaldi, made by Gilead Sciences, normally costs about $1,000 a pill.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: After Dog Rescues, Chinese Activists Left With a Daunting Task
item.description: Bills keep mounting for animal welfare advocates who have stepped forward to take responsibility for hundreds of dogs recently seized by the authorities in China.
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:credit: Humane Society International, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rescued dogs lie in the shade of a truck that was transporting them to be slaughtered and sold as meat on Aug. 12 in suburban Beijing.

item.title: Australia Unveils Its Plan to Protect Great Barrier Reef
item.description: Hoping to forestall a move by Unesco to put the reef on its list of endangered World Heritage sites, officials said they would set conservation targets.
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: The Great Barrier Reef is under threat from climate change, poor water quality and the impact of coastal development.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Great Unraveling
item.description: A time of weakness and hatred, disorientation and doubt, when nobody can see what disaster looms.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROGER COHEN

item.title: Police Detain Tie Liu, Beijing Writer and Underground Publisher
item.description: After charging the 81-year-old with “creating a disturbance,” officers hauled away computers and his cellphone, as well as books and periodicals.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Burning Man-Style Finale for a Giant Rabbit in Taiwan
item.description: An 82-foot-tall rabbit created by the Dutch artist Florentijn Hofman met with a calamitous end, catching fire as it was being disassembled after drawing huge crowds at an arts festival in Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Syrian Leaders See Opportunities and Risks in U.S. Striking ISIS on Their Soil
item.description: Analysts say Syrian officials are unsure who would benefit militarily if the United States launches strikes against ISIS in Syria — government forces, or Syrian insurgents and separatist Kurds.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Hadi Bahra, the president of the opposition Syrian National Coalition, has called for the defeat of ISIS and the government.
